user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                                     size_t quoted_len,
                                     const char *unquoted,
                                     size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (! charsequalcaseless (quoted[i], unquoted[j]))
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_bin_n:
_MHD_static_inline bool
charsequalcaseless (const char c1, const char c2)
{
  return ( (c1 == c2) ||
           (isasciiupper (c1) ?
            ((c1 - 'A' + 'a') == c2) :
            ((c1 == (c2 - 'A' + 'a')) && isasciiupper (c2))) );
}
...
_MHD_static_inline bool
isasciiupper (char c)
{
  return (c >= 'A') && (c <= 'Z');
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (! charsequalcaseless (quoted[i], unquoted[j]))
      return false; /* Different characters */

if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */
explanation: I have listed all code fragments that could plausibly contain operations that are executed yet redundant or whose removal might not change behavior (these should be investigated for possible dead code or redundant checks). Other parts of the function that were not listed are not suspicious for Rule 2.2 for the following reasons: initializations (size_t i; size_t j; j = 0; i = 0 in the loop) are necessary state setup (initialization is explicitly excluded from dead-code candidates per the rule notes); the loop body increments (++i, ++j) and the final return true implement the essential matching logic and are required for correct behaviour; comments and obvious control-flow constructs are not executable operations that could be dead; and each early-return that I did not include (for example the explicit return true at the end) directly affects the function result so its removal would change behaviour. The fragments I selected cover conditional checks, branch logic and helper functions that contain conditional expressions which may be redundant or otherwise candidates for dead code; those should be examined further.
